      '\r\n' +
      '### Heuristics: Mental Shortcuts\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      "Your brain processes millions of data points every second. It **can't** analyze everything rationally, so it uses **heuristics**ΓÇömental shortcuts to make fast decisions with limited information.\r\n" +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Why we need them:**\r\n' +

      '### Biases: Systematic Errors\r\n' +

      'When heuristics consistently lead us astray, we get **cognitive biases**ΓÇöpredictable patterns of irrationality.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Key insight from Kahneman & Tversky (1970s):**\r\n' +
      "These aren't random mistakes. They're systematic, repeatable errors hardwired into how we think.\r\n" +
      '\r\n' +
      '## The Major Cognitive Biases\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '### 1. Availability Heuristic\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**The bias**: Judging likelihood based on how easily examples come to mind.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Example:**\r\n' +
      '- People fear plane crashes more than car accidents\r\n' +
      '- Plane crashes are memorable and widely reported\r\n' +
      '- Car accidents kill far more people\r\n' +
      '- Your brain says: "I can easily imagine plane crashes = must be common"\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Where it appears (2024 research):**\r\n' +
      '- Risk assessment\r\n' +
      '- Medical diagnosis\r\n' +
      '- Investment decisions\r\n' +
      '- Fear responses to rare but vivid events\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      "**Why it's dangerous:**\r\n" +
      '- Vivid Γëá frequent\r\n' +
      '- Media coverage distorts perception\r\n' +
      '- Recent events feel more likely than they are\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '### 2. Confirmation Bias\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**The bias**: Seeking information that confirms existing beliefs while ignoring contradictory evidence.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Example:**\r\n' +
      '- Believe vaccines are dangerous ΓåÆ only read anti-vax sources\r\n' +
      '- Believe climate change is fake ΓåÆ dismiss scientific consensus\r\n' +
      "- Believe your team will win ΓåÆ ignore evidence they won't\r\n" +
      '\r\n' +
      '**How it works:**\r\n' +
      '- We notice evidence supporting our views\r\n' +
      '- We dismiss evidence contradicting our views\r\n' +
      '- We interpret ambiguous evidence as supportive\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**The result**: Beliefs become unfalsifiable, immune to evidence.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '### 3. Anchoring and Adjustment\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**The bias**: Relying heavily on the first piece of information encountered (the "anchor") and insufficiently adjusting from it.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Classic experiment:**\r\n' +
      '- Spin a wheel (random): lands on 10 or 65\r\n' +
      '- Question: What percentage of African nations are in the UN?\r\n' +
      '- People who saw 10 guessed ~25%\r\n' +
      '- People who saw 65 guessed ~45%\r\n' +
      '- **The random number influenced their estimate!**\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Real-world impact:**\r\n' +
      '- Salary negotiations (first offer anchors)\r\n' +
      '- Real estate pricing (asking price anchors)\r\n' +
      "- Legal damages (plaintiff's demand anchors)\r\n" +
      '\r\n' +
      '### 4. Representativeness Heuristic\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**The bias**: Judging probability based on how much something resembles a stereotype.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Famous example (Linda problem):**\r\n' +
      '*Linda is 31, single, outspoken, and very bright. She majored in philosophy and was concerned with discrimination and social justice.*\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '*Which is more probable:*\r\n' +
      '- A) Linda is a bank teller\r\n' +
      '- B) Linda is a bank teller and active in the feminist movement\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      'Most people choose BΓÇöwhich is **mathematically impossible**. B is a subset of A and therefore cannot be more probable.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Why we fall for it**: Description matches our "feminist" stereotype, so B "feels" right.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '### 5. Overconfidence Bias\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**The bias**: Systematically overestimating the accuracy of our judgments.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Research findings:**\r\n' +
      '- Experts are just as prone as laypeople\r\n' +
      '- Appears in medicine, finance, management, law\r\n' +
      '- Particularly dangerous because it feels like competence\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Examples:**\r\n' +
      '- 80% of drivers rate themselves "above average" (mathematically impossible)\r\n' +
      '- Doctors overconfident in diagnoses (leads to diagnostic errors)\r\n' +
      '- Investors overestimate their ability to beat the market\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '### 6. Planning Fallacy\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**The bias**: Underestimating how long tasks will take.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Why it happens:**\r\n' +
      '- We imagine ideal scenarios\r\n' +
      '- We ignore past experiences of delays\r\n' +
      '- We assume *this time* will be different\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Result**: Chronic lateness, budget overruns, deadline failures.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '### 7. Outcome Bias\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**The bias**: Judging a decision by its outcome rather than its quality at the time.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Example:**\r\n' +
      '- A doctor makes the right diagnosis with available information\r\n' +
      '- Patient dies anyway (rare complication)\r\n' +
      '- Colleagues judge the decision as "bad" because outcome was bad\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      "**Why it's flawed**: Good decisions can have bad outcomes. Bad decisions can have good outcomes. Judging by results alone is irrational.\r\n" +
      '\r\n' +
      '### 8. Status Quo Bias\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**The bias**: Preferring things to stay the same; resisting change even when change is beneficial.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Manifestations:**\r\n' +
      '- Keeping terrible jobs\r\n' +
      '- Staying in bad relationships\r\n' +
      '- Maintaining outdated systems\r\n' +
      '- Default options have outsized influence\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '## Biases in Professional Domains (2024 Research)\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '### Medicine\r\n' +

      '\r\n' +
      '### Finance\r\n' +

      '**Impact**: Poor returns, market bubbles\r\n' +

      '\r\n' +
      '## The Major Cognitive Biases\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '### 1. Availability Heuristic\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**The bias**: Judging likelihood based on how easily examples come to mind.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Example:**\r\n' +
      '- People fear plane crashes more than car accidents\r\n' +
      '- Plane crashes are memorable and widely reported\r\n' +

      '- Your brain says: "I can easily imagine plane crashes = must be common"\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Where it appears (2024 research):**\r\n' +
      '- Risk assessment\r\n' +
      '- Medical diagnosis\r\n' +
      '- Investment decisions\r\n' +

      '\r\n' +
      "**Why it's dangerous:**\r\n" +
      '- Vivid Γëá frequent\r\n' +
      '- Media coverage distorts perception\r\n' +
      '- Recent events feel more likely than they are\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '### 2. Confirmation Bias\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**The bias**: Seeking information that confirms existing beliefs while ignoring contradictory evidence.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Example:**\r\n' +
      '- Believe vaccines are dangerous ΓåÆ only read anti-vax sources\r\n' +
      '- Believe climate change is fake ΓåÆ dismiss scientific consensus\r\n' +

      '\r\n' +
      '**How it works:**\r\n' +
      '- We notice evidence supporting our views\r\n' +
      '- We dismiss evidence contradicting our views\r\n' +
      '- We interpret ambiguous evidence as supportive\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**The result**: Beliefs become unfalsifiable, immune to evidence.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '### 3. Anchoring and Adjustment\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**The bias**: Relying heavily on the first piece of information encountered (the "anchor") and insufficiently adjusting from it.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Classic experiment:**\r\n' +
      '- Spin a wheel (random): lands on 10 or 65\r\n' +
      '- Question: What percentage of African nations are in the UN?\r\n' +
      '- People who saw 10 guessed ~25%\r\n' +
      '- People who saw 65 guessed ~45%\r\n' +
      '- **The random number influenced their estimate!**\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Real-world impact:**\r\n' +
      '- Salary negotiations (first offer anchors)\r\n' +
      '- Real estate pricing (asking price anchors)\r\n' +
      "- Legal damages (plaintiff's demand anchors)\r\n" +
      '\r\n' +
      '### 4. Representativeness Heuristic\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**The bias**: Judging probability based on how much something resembles a stereotype.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Famous example (Linda problem):**\r\n' +
      '*Linda is 31, single, outspoken, and very bright. She majored in philosophy and was concerned with discrimination and social justice.*\r\n' +

      '*Which is more probable:*\r\n' +

      '- B) Linda is a bank teller and active in the feminist movement\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      'Most people choose BΓÇöwhich is **mathematically impossible**. B is a subset of A and therefore cannot be more probable.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Why we fall for it**: Description matches our "feminist" stereotype, so B "feels" right.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '### 5. Overconfidence Bias\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**The bias**: Systematically overestimating the accuracy of our judgments.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Research findings:**\r\n' +
      '- Experts are just as prone as laypeople\r\n' +
      '- Appears in medicine, finance, management, law\r\n' +

      '\r\n' +
      '### 6. Planning Fallacy\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**The bias**: Underestimating how long tasks will take.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Why it happens:**\r\n' +
      '- We imagine ideal scenarios\r\n' +
      '- We ignore past experiences of delays\r\n' +
      '- We assume *this time* will be different\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Result**: Chronic lateness, budget overruns, deadline failures.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '### 7. Outcome Bias\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**The bias**: Judging a decision by its outcome rather than its quality at the time.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Example:**\r\n' +
      '- A doctor makes the right diagnosis with available information\r\n' +

      '\r\n' +
      "**Why it's flawed**: Good decisions can have bad outcomes. Bad decisions can have good outcomes. Judging by results alone is irrational.\r\n" +
      '\r\n' +
      '### 8. Status Quo Bias\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**The bias**: Preferring things to stay the same; resisting change even when change is beneficial.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Manifestations:**\r\n' +
      '- Keeping terrible jobs\r\n' +
      '- Staying in bad relationships\r\n' +
      '- Maintaining outdated systems\r\n' +

      'title: "Why Smart People Make Terrible Decisions: The Cognitive Biases Controlling Your Brain"\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '## What Are Heuristics and Biases?\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '### Heuristics: Mental Shortcuts\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      "Your brain processes millions of data points every second. It **can't** analyze everything rationally, so it uses **heuristics**ΓÇömental shortcuts to make fast decisions with limited information.\r\n" +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Why we need them:**\r\n' +
      '- Processing capacity is limited\r\n' +
      '- Decisions often require speed\r\n' +
      '- Perfect information is impossible\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**The problem:**\r\n' +
      '- Shortcuts that usually work sometimes catastrophically fail\r\n' +
      "- We don't notice we're using them\r\n" +
      "- Intelligence doesn't protect against them\r\n" +
      '\r\n' +
      '### Biases: Systematic Errors\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      'When heuristics consistently lead us astray, we get **cognitive biases**ΓÇöpredictable patterns of irrationality.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Key insight from Kahneman & Tversky (1970s):**\r\n' +
      "These aren't random mistakes. They're systematic, repeatable errors hardwired into how we think.\r\n" +
      '\r\n' +
      '## The Major Cognitive Biases\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '### 1. Availability Heuristic\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**The bias**: Judging likelihood based on how easily examples come to mind.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Example:**\r\n' +
      '- People fear plane crashes more than car accidents\r\n' +
      '- Plane crashes are memorable and widely reported\r\n' +
      '- Car accidents kill far more people\r\n' +
      '- Your brain says: "I can easily imagine plane crashes = must be common"\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Where it appears (2024 research):**\r\n' +
      '- Risk assessment\r\n' +
      '- Medical diagnosis\r\n' +
      '- Investment decisions\r\n' +
      '- Fear responses to rare but vivid events\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      "**Why it's dangerous:**\r\n" +
      '- Vivid Γëá frequent\r\n' +
      '- Media coverage distorts perception\r\n' +
      '- Recent events feel more likely than they are\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '### 2. Confirmation Bias\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**The bias**: Seeking information that confirms existing beliefs while ignoring contradictory evidence.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Example:**\r\n' +
      '- Believe vaccines are dangerous ΓåÆ only read anti-vax sources\r\n' +
      '- Believe climate change is fake ΓåÆ dismiss scientific consensus\r\n' +
      "- Believe your team will win ΓåÆ ignore evidence they won't\r\n" +
      '\r\n' +
      '**How it works:**\r\n' +
      '- We notice evidence supporting our views\r\n' +
      '- We dismiss evidence contradicting our views\r\n' +
      '- We interpret ambiguous evidence as supportive\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**The result**: Beliefs become unfalsifiable, immune to evidence.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '### 3. Anchoring and Adjustment\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**The bias**: Relying heavily on the first piece of information encountered (the "anchor") and insufficiently adjusting from it.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Classic experiment:**\r\n' +
      '- Spin a wheel (random): lands on 10 or 65\r\n' +
      '- Question: What percentage of African nations are in the UN?\r\n' +
      '- People who saw 10 guessed ~25%\r\n' +
      '- People who saw 65 guessed ~45%\r\n' +
      '- **The random number influenced their estimate!**\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Real-world impact:**\r\n' +
      '- Salary negotiations (first offer anchors)\r\n' +
      '- Real estate pricing (asking price anchors)\r\n' +
      "- Legal damages (plaintiff's demand anchors)\r\n" +
      '\r\n' +
      '### 4. Representativeness Heuristic\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**The bias**: Judging probability based on how much something resembles a stereotype.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Famous example (Linda problem):**\r\n' +
      '*Linda is 31, single, outspoken, and very bright. She majored in philosophy and was concerned with discrimination and social justice.*\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '*Which is more probable:*\r\n' +
      '- A) Linda is a bank teller\r\n' +
      '- B) Linda is a bank teller and active in the feminist movement\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      'Most people choose BΓÇöwhich is **mathematically impossible**. B is a subset of A and therefore cannot be more probable.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Why we fall for it**: Description matches our "feminist" stereotype, so B "feels" right.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '### 5. Overconfidence Bias\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**The bias**: Systematically overestimating the accuracy of our judgments.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Research findings:**\r\n' +
      '- Experts are just as prone as laypeople\r\n' +
      '- Appears in medicine, finance, management, law\r\n' +
      '- Particularly dangerous because it feels like competence\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Examples:**\r\n' +
      '- 80% of drivers rate themselves "above average" (mathematically impossible)\r\n' +
      '- Doctors overconfident in diagnoses (leads to diagnostic errors)\r\n' +
      '- Investors overestimate their ability to beat the market\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '### 6. Planning Fallacy\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**The bias**: Underestimating how long tasks will take.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Why it happens:**\r\n' +
      '- We imagine ideal scenarios\r\n' +
      '- We ignore past experiences of delays\r\n' +
      '- We assume *this time* will be different\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Result**: Chronic lateness, budget overruns, deadline failures.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '### 7. Outcome Bias\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**The bias**: Judging a decision by its outcome rather than its quality at the time.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Example:**\r\n' +
      '- A doctor makes the right diagnosis with available information\r\n' +
      '- Patient dies anyway (rare complication)\r\n' +
      '- Colleagues judge the decision as "bad" because outcome was bad\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      "**Why it's flawed**: Good decisions can have bad outcomes. Bad decisions can have good outcomes. Judging by results alone is irrational.\r\n" +
      '\r\n' +
      '### 8. Status Quo Bias\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**The bias**: Preferring things to stay the same; resisting change even when change is beneficial.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Manifestations:**\r\n' +
      '- Keeping terrible jobs\r\n' +
      '- Staying in bad relationships\r\n' +
      '- Maintaining outdated systems\r\n' +
      '- Default options have outsized influence\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '## Biases in Professional Domains (2024 Research)\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '### Medicine\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Common biases:**\r\n' +
      '- **Availability**: Recent cases influence diagnosis\r\n' +
      '- **  Anchoring**: Initial diagnosis sticks even with new evidence\r\n' +
      '- **Overconfidence**: Failure to reconsider or seek second opinions\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Impact**: Diagnostic errors, treatment mistakes\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '### Finance\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Common biases:**\r\n' +
      '- **Overconfidence**: Trading too frequently, poor diversification\r\n' +
      '- **Recency bias**: Assuming recent trends will continue\r\n' +
      '- **Loss aversion**: Holding losing investments too long\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Impact**: Poor returns, market bubbles\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '### Law\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Common biases:**\r\n' +
      '- **Confirmation**: Seeking evidence of guilt, ignoring exculpatory evidence\r\n' +
      "- **Anchoring**: Sentenced influenced by prosecutor's recommendation\r\n" +
      '- **Representativeness**: Stereotyping defendants\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Impact**: Wrongful convictions, unjust sentences\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '## The AI Bias Problem (2024)\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '### LLMs Inherit Human Biases\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +

      '\r\n' +
      '## What Are Heuristics and Biases?\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '### Heuristics: Mental Shortcuts\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      "Your brain processes millions of data points every second. It **can't** analyze everything rationally, so it uses **heuristics**ΓÇömental shortcuts to make fast decisions with limited information.\r\n" +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Why we need them:**\r\n' +
      '- Processing capacity is limited\r\n' +
      '- Decisions often require speed\r\n' +

      '\r\n' +
      '### Biases: Systematic Errors\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      'When heuristics consistently lead us astray, we get **cognitive biases**ΓÇöpredictable patterns of irrationality.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Key insight from Kahneman & Tversky (1970s):**\r\n' +
      "These aren't random mistakes. They're systematic, repeatable errors hardwired into how we think.\r\n" +
      '\r\n' +
      '## The Major Cognitive Biases\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '### 1. Availability Heuristic\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**The bias**: Judging likelihood based on how easily examples come to mind.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Example:**\r\n' +
      '- People fear plane crashes more than car accidents\r\n' +
      '- Plane crashes are memorable and widely reported\r\n' +
      '- Car accidents kill far more people\r\n' +
      '- Your brain says: "I can easily imagine plane crashes = must be common"\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Where it appears (2024 research):**\r\n' +
      '- Risk assessment\r\n' +
      '- Medical diagnosis\r\n' +
      '- Investment decisions\r\n' +
      '- Fear responses to rare but vivid events\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      "**Why it's dangerous:**\r\n" +
      '- Vivid Γëá frequent\r\n' +
      '- Media coverage distorts perception\r\n' +
      '- Recent events feel more likely than they are\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '### 2. Confirmation Bias\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**The bias**: Seeking information that confirms existing beliefs while ignoring contradictory evidence.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Example:**\r\n' +
      '- Believe vaccines are dangerous ΓåÆ only read anti-vax sources\r\n' +
      '- Believe climate change is fake ΓåÆ dismiss scientific consensus\r\n' +
      "- Believe your team will win ΓåÆ ignore evidence they won't\r\n" +
      '\r\n' +
      '**How it works:**\r\n' +
      '- We notice evidence supporting our views\r\n' +
      '- We dismiss evidence contradicting our views\r\n' +
      '- We interpret ambiguous evidence as supportive\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**The result**: Beliefs become unfalsifiable, immune to evidence.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '### 3. Anchoring and Adjustment\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**The bias**: Relying heavily on the first piece of information encountered (the "anchor") and insufficiently adjusting from it.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Classic experiment:**\r\n' +
      '- Spin a wheel (random): lands on 10 or 65\r\n' +
      '- Question: What percentage of African nations are in the UN?\r\n' +
      '- People who saw 10 guessed ~25%\r\n' +
      '- People who saw 65 guessed ~45%\r\n' +
      '- **The random number influenced their estimate!**\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Real-world impact:**\r\n' +
      '- Salary negotiations (first offer anchors)\r\n' +
      '- Real estate pricing (asking price anchors)\r\n' +
      "- Legal damages (plaintiff's demand anchors)\r\n" +
      '\r\n' +
      '### 4. Representativeness Heuristic\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**The bias**: Judging probability based on how much something resembles a stereotype.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Famous example (Linda problem):**\r\n' +
      '*Linda is 31, single, outspoken, and very bright. She majored in philosophy and was concerned with discrimination and social justice.*\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '*Which is more probable:*\r\n' +
      '- A) Linda is a bank teller\r\n' +
      '- B) Linda is a bank teller and active in the feminist movement\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      'Most people choose BΓÇöwhich is **mathematically impossible**. B is a subset of A and therefore cannot be more probable.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Why we fall for it**: Description matches our "feminist" stereotype, so B "feels" right.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '### 5. Overconfidence Bias\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**The bias**: Systematically overestimating the accuracy of our judgments.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Research findings:**\r\n' +
      '- Experts are just as prone as laypeople\r\n' +
      '- Appears in medicine, finance, management, law\r\n' +
      '- Particularly dangerous because it feels like competence\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Examples:**\r\n' +
      '- 80% of drivers rate themselves "above average" (mathematically impossible)\r\n' +
      '- Doctors overconfident in diagnoses (leads to diagnostic errors)\r\n' +
      '- Investors overestimate their ability to beat the market\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '### 6. Planning Fallacy\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**The bias**: Underestimating how long tasks will take.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Why it happens:**\r\n' +
      '- We imagine ideal scenarios\r\n' +
      '- We ignore past experiences of delays\r\n' +
      '- We assume *this time* will be different\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Result**: Chronic lateness, budget overruns, deadline failures.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '### 7. Outcome Bias\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**The bias**: Judging a decision by its outcome rather than its quality at the time.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Example:**\r\n' +
      '- A doctor makes the right diagnosis with available information\r\n' +
      '- Patient dies anyway (rare complication)\r\n' +
      '- Colleagues judge the decision as "bad" because outcome was bad\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      "**Why it's flawed**: Good decisions can have bad outcomes. Bad decisions can have good outcomes. Judging by results alone is irrational.\r\n" +
      '\r\n' +
      '### 8. Status Quo Bias\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**The bias**: Preferring things to stay the same; resisting change even when change is beneficial.\r\n' +
      '\r\n' +
      '**Manifestations:**\r\n' +
      '- Keeping terrible jobs\r\n' +
      '- Staying in bad relationships\r\n' +
      '- Maintaining outdated systems\r\n' +
      '- Default options have outsized influence\r\n' +
